image.altText: A middle-aged woman with blonde hair, sunglasses and a dark cap smiles holding a box of keepcups labelled 'walking cups'.

items.synopsis: There isn't a whole lot of consistency in Australia around what single-use plastics are being phased out and when. See what's happening in your state.

title.children: Kitchen benches are still killing young tradies — and we know how to stop it

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market begins its day higher ahead of tomorrow's Reserve Bank decision, which is widely expected to be a "pause" in its interest-rate-hiking cycle. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises as markets bet on RBA pausing interest rate hikes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has begun its week slightly higher, with the industrials and energy sectors posting the largest gains. The ASX 200 index was up 0.3% by 11am AEST. Lynas Rare Earths was one of the best-perfroming stocks, after its share price jumped 4%. This was despite the company revealing its fourth-quarter revenue plunged 47% (as it was hurt by lower market prices for rare earth products during the quarter). The world's largest producer of rare earths outside of China said sales revenue was $157.5 million for the three months ended June 30 (compared with $294.5 million a year ago). On the other hand, shares of IGO fell 4.1% despite the lithium miner reporting a small increase in its June quarter sales revenue, compared to the same period last year. However, the worst performer was Silver Lake Resources. The gold miner's share price plunged 23.1% after it released quarterly results which fell below market expectations.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX lifts despite mixed performance from mining stocks

children.content: The Australian share market has begun its week slightly higher, with the industrials and energy sectors posting the largest gains.
The ASX 200 index was up 0.3% by 11am AEST.
Lynas Rare Earths
was one of the best-perfroming stocks, after its share price jumped 4%.
This was despite the company revealing its fourth-quarter revenue plunged 47% (as it was hurt by lower market prices for rare earth products during the quarter).
The world's largest producer of rare earths outside of China said sales revenue was $157.5 million for the three months ended June 30 (compared with $294.5 million a year ago).
On the other hand, shares of
IGO
fell 4.1% despite the lithium miner
reporting a small increase in its June quarter sales revenue, compared to the same period last year.
However, the worst performer was
Silver Lake Resources
The gold miner's share price plunged 23.1% after it released quarterly results which fell below market expectations.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The likelihood of whether the Reserve Bank will lift interest rates or not at its next meeting (August 1) has fluctuated wildly in the past few weeks. The ASX's RBA Rate Indicator shows, on July 21, the odds of a rate hike surged to 48% after the Bureau of Statistics revealed the unemployment rate remained steady at 3.5% (near its lowest level in 50 years). Five days later, the probability fell to 14% when the ABS announced that inflation fell at quicker-than-expected pace in the June quarter. The odds continued to fall on Friday (down to 8% ), after the latest retail sales figures came in worse-than-expected:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets pricing in 8% chance of Reserve Bank rate hike, according to ASX indictator

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through the latest business and economic news. The local share market is likely to open higher, with ASX futures suggesting a 0.3% rise in morning trade. It comes after a strong finish on Wall Street last Friday (US time), which saw the Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rise 0.5%, 1% and 1.9% respectively. In economic news, the key event is tomorrow's Reserve Bank board meeting. Markets are betting the likelihood of of an interest rate hike is around 20%, according to Refinitiv data. However, economists from Westpac, Commonwealth Bank and other places are predicting the RBA will (more likely than not) lift its cash rate target. If the RBA keeps rates on hold, it would mean the cash rate remains at a decade high of 4.1% .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to rise ahead of tomorrow's RBA decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has told reporters he has no recollection or record of being briefed by the Australian Federal Police before the former government entered into contracts with a man suspected of bribing Nauruan officials. Dutton has told reporters in Canberra this morning that he would happily co-sign a letter with the prime minister referring the matters to the National Anti-Corruption Commission. He says he is "in the crossfire" of attacks between Home Affairs Minister Clare O’Neil and her department secretary, Michael Pezzullo. You can read more about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Dutton says he's in the 'crossfire' of attacks within the Home Affairs Department

featuredLink.title: Dutton 'happy to co-sign' referral to anti-corruption watchdog over Nauru contracts

props.alt: Peter Dutton in front of a blue wall.

children.content: (ABC News)
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has told reporters he has no recollection or record of being briefed by the Australian Federal Police before the
former government entered into contracts with a man suspected
of bribing Nauruan officials.
Dutton has told reporters in Canberra this morning that he would happily co-sign a letter with the prime minister referring the matters to the National
Anti-Corruption Commission.
He says he is "in the crossfire" of attacks between Home Affairs Minister Clare O’Neil and her department secretary, Michael Pezzullo.
You can read more about this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian tennis warrior Alexei Popyrin has overcome severe leg cramping to outlast triple grand slam champion Stan Wawrinka to claim his second ATP Tour 250 title. Popyrin rallied from a set down to defeat Wawrinka 6-7 (5-7) 6-3 6-4 in a Croatian Open final in Umag that stretched past two and a half hours. "All tournament I've been fighting battles that I don't know how I won. This one tops it all," Popyrin says. "My quad was done at 2-1. I felt it cramp, I felt it strain. I think it's pulled. "But I managed to dig deep. I don't know how I won it, honestly. I honestly don't know."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia's Alexei Popyrin defeats Stan Wawrinka to win the Croatian Open

props.alt: A male tennis player clenching a fist and celebrating during a match, holding a racket in the other hand

children.content: (AAP: James Ross)
Australian tennis warrior Alexei Popyrin has overcome severe leg cramping to outlast triple grand slam champion Stan Wawrinka to claim his second ATP Tour 250 title.
Popyrin rallied from a set down to defeat Wawrinka 6-7 (5-7) 6-3 6-4
in a Croatian Open final in Umag that stretched past two and a half hours.
"All tournament I've been fighting battles that I don't know how I won. This one tops it all," Popyrin says.
"My quad was done at 2-1. I felt it cramp, I felt it strain. I think it's pulled.
"But I managed to dig deep. I don't know how I won it, honestly. I honestly don't know."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Defence Personnel Matt Keogh has told ABC News Breakfast his number one priority is finding the missing crew members of the crashed Taipan helicopter off Hamilton Island. Captain Danniel Lyon, Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent, Warrant Officer Class Two Joseph Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs were on board the MRH90 helicopter that ditched into the ocean during a training exercise as part of Exercise Talisman Sabre on Friday night. Mr Keogh said the search has involved Australian Defence Force personnel, United States Defence Force, as well as Queensland emergency services. "This is our first priority," he said. "It is finding our four missing Defence Force members. As well as providing support to their families at this difficult time when their family members are missing. And that remains our key priority. "As you'll appreciate, there are people involved in this search that are part of the defence family for the four that are missing as well and they're throwing everything at finding them as soon as we can."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Helicopter crash search 'first priority' for defence force

mediaThumbnail.caption: Defence Personnel Minister Matt Keogh says the incident highlights the risk faced by members of the armed forces.
